de.mrapp.android.validation.validators

Class AbstractValidator<Type>

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.mrapp.android.validation.validators.AbstractValidator<Type>
  • Type Parameters:
    Type - The type of the values, which should be validated
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Validator<Type>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BeginsWithUppercaseLetterValidator, ConjunctiveValidator, DisjunctiveValidator, EqualValidator, LetterOrNumberValidator, LetterValidator, MaxLengthValidator, MinLengthValidator, NegateValidator, NotEmptyValidator, NotNullValidator, NoWhitespaceValidator, RegexValidator

    public abstract class AbstractValidator<Type>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Validator<Type>
    An abstract base class for all validators, which should be able to validate values of a specific type.
    Since:
    1.0.0

    • Constructor Detail

      • AbstractValidator

        public AbstractValidator(@NonNull
                         java.lang.CharSequence errorMessage)
        Creates a new validator, which should be able to validate values of a specific type.
        Parameters:
        errorMessage - The error message, which should be shown, if the validation fails, as an instance of the type CharSequence. The error message may not be null

      • AbstractValidator

        public AbstractValidator(@NonNull
                         android.content.Context context,
                         @StringRes
                         int resourceId)
        Creates a new validator, which should be able to validate values of a specific type.
        Parameters:
        context - The context, which should be used to retrieve the error message, as an instance of the class Context. The context may not be null
        resourceId - The resource ID of the string resource, which contains the error message, which should be set, as an Integer value. The resource ID must correspond to a valid string resource

        Parameters:

        resourceId - The resource ID of the string resource, which contains the error message, which should be set, as an Integer value. The resource ID must correspond to a valid string resource

      • setIcon

        public final void setIcon(@Nullable
                          android.graphics.drawable.Drawable icon)
        Sets the icon, which should be shown, if the validation fails.
        Parameters:
        icon - The icon, which should be set, as an instance of the class Drawable or null, if no icon should be shown

      • setIcon

        public final void setIcon(@NonNull
                          android.content.Context context,
                          @DrawableRes
                          int resourceId)
        Sets the icon, which should be shown, if the validation fails.
        Parameters:
        context - The context, which should be used to retrieve the icon, as an instance of the class Context. The context may not be null
        resourceId - The resource ID of the drawable resource, which contains the icon, which should be set, as an Integer value. The resource ID must correspond to a valid drawable resource
